ul.li: An algebraic fraction (or rational expression, as they are sometimes called) is a fraction in which both numerator and denominator are polynomials.
An algebraic fraction is undefined at any values of the variable that make the denominator equal to zero.
We use the fundamental principle of fractions to reduce or build fractions.

assemblage.title: Fundamental Principle of Fractions
assemblage.p: We can multiply or divide the numerator and denominator of a fraction by the same nonzero factor, and the new fraction will be equivalent to the old one. \blert{\dfrac{a \cdot c}{b \cdot c} = \dfrac{a}{b}~~~\text{if}~~~b,~c \not= 0}

ol.li: Divide numerator and denominator by any common factors.

ul.li: We can cancel common factors (expressions that are multiplied together), but not common terms (expressions that are added or subtracted).
A fraction is a negative number if either its numerator or its denominator is negative, but not both.

assemblage.title: Negative of a Binomial
assemblage.p: The opposite of a-b is \blert{-(a-b) = -a+b = b-a}

ol.li: Factor each numerator and denominator completely.
If any factor appears in both a numerator and a denominator, divide out that factor.
Multiply the remaining factors of the numerator and the remaining factors of the denominator.

assemblage.title: To Divide One Fraction by Another

ol.li: Take the reciprocal of the second fraction and change the division to multiplication.
Follow the rules for multiplication of fractions.

ul.li: Fractions with the same denominator are called like fractions.

assemblage.title: Sum or Difference of Like Fractions
To Add or Subtract Like Fractions

ol.li: Reduce the sum or difference if necessary.

ul.li: To add or subtract fractions with unlike denominators, we must first convert the fractions to equivalent forms with the same denominator.
The lowest common denominator for two or more algebraic fractions is the simplest algebraic expression that is a multiple of each denominator.

ol.li: Factor each denominator completely, and arrange the factors in order.

li.p:
For each factor,
Which denominator has the most copies of that factor? Circle them. (If there is a tie, either denominator will do.)
Include all the circled factors in the LCD.

ol.li: Multiply together the factors of the LCD.

assemblage.title: To Add or Subtract Algebraic Fractions

ol.li: Find the lowest common denominator (LCD) for the fractions.
Build each fraction to an equivalent one with the LCD as denominator.
Add or subtract the resulting like fractions: Add or subtract their numerators, and keep the same denominator.
Reduce the sum or difference if necessary.

ul.li: To solve an equation that contains algebraic fractions, we first clear the denominators by multiplying both sides of the equation by the LCD of the fractions.
When clearing fractions from am equation, we must be sure to multiply each term of the equation by the LCD.
Whenever we multiply an equation by an expression containing the variable, we should check for extraneous solutions.
